transcript.content: Pete Yorn, For Nancy, on Xfm 104.9.  I’m Ricky Gervais, with me, Steve, Merchant,
Hello there.
Karl.  Pilkington.
Steve, got any other toilet-related, anecdotes?
Steve laughs
Rick, my life is just full of toilet trauma.
Yeah.

And I’ve, Karl – you may not realize this, but, uh, awhile back I used to host – this is bizarre – I used to host a radio show, on the BBC World Service, right?  Now, you, if you want someone who’s the voice of integrity, the voice of intelligence, the voice of a nation, you’re gonna come to me.
Yeah.

That’s obvious.  And I was broadcasting to – now they’ve got listeners of something like 50, 60 million people around the world.  It’s mental, the listenership, of the World Service.  And, I used to host this show with someone else,
It’s a big place, Steve.
The world?
Yeah.

You’re absolutely right.  And uh, anyway, so I had to, I had to be in to Bush House where they broadcast from, 10 o’clock, every Friday morning, to broadcast ‘round the world, to 50 million people, right?   And one week, uh, went to the toilet, in my house, right, everyone had left.  I got there a bit late, I, got up a bit late, already against me.  The clock was already against me.  Had to be there at 10 o’clock, broadcast around the world, and we got 2 toilets in our house, downstairs one, right, and the door had already been a bit dodgy, it was one of those doors where you had to give it a bit of a kick as you went in.  It was gettin’, it was gettin’ a bit tight, I don’t know what, wood was expanding or something.  I’m in there, and, same thing again happens.  No toilet paper.  I think, Oh God, I’m gonna have to somehow kinda make it upstairs,
Why don’t you check, first.
I normally do, Rick!  I normally do.  It’s just on a certain occasions when I’m bleary-eyed or something I just, I forget.  Or I occasionally I forget.  Normally I do check.
Right.
And um, you’ve got to bear in mind that it’s not like this is happening every week.  This is over the coarse of many years,
Sure.
That these instances have accumulated.
You’ve condensed them.  For
For purposes of this anecdote.
Sure.
Yeah.  Yes.  And um,
Ricky giggles
Great.  Brilliant.  Keeping the pace up of an anecdote there, Rick, you’ve just drawn in – I don’t know where I am now.  Anyway – oh, I know where I am – I’m trapped in a toilet with no toilet paper.
Yeah.
And I’m thinkin’, Maybe I’ll peel off some of the wallpaper, you know, things like that, but there’s nothing I can do,
Newspaper.
Well exactly, but I - I go upstairs, and find,
Toilet paper!  Was there any?
There wasn’t, sadly,
Wasn’t?  All right.

I’d have to go upstairs and maybe find a notepad or something like that.  And uh, so I try the door, and the door is wedged, and I’m pulling on the door, and I can’t, get the door open.  And it’s just like, and I’m already, I knew it was gonna come to this at some point, this is like, the clock’s ticking, I’m trying to pull the door open, trousers around my ankles again, and I’m thinkin’, well what I can do, I can open the window, I suppose, and like try and climb out, but, not really, ‘cause I’ve got the trousers ‘round the ankles,
Or if it was raining, just stick your arse out, two birds with one stone!
Sadly, it was a beautiful day, Rick.
It’s – I call it the World Bidet.
Steve laughs
And so um, what I’m thinkin’ is, I wonder, I’ve got my mobile phone in there, ‘cause I’m, it’s in my pocket, I’m thinking well maybe I’ll phone, seriously,
Kleenex!
Ricky giggles
Well maybe I’ll phone the fire brigade!
At this point, hadn’t it just dried?
Ricky laughs
No, it hadn’t!  It was, it was,
Hold on – was that little puppy not around?  ‘Cause some, sometimes you can call that, it’s got a little bit wrapped ‘round it!
Listen.
Or just use the puppy itself!
There’s 50 million people around the world, waiting to hear my voice in like 30 minutes,
Yeah?  Yeah?  Exactly.
And –
(In indistinguishable foreign accent) Where is Steve?  He is not locked in a toilet again, is he?
Steve laughs
Exactly.
Oh no!
So um, so I’m thinking about phoning the fire brigade,
Sure.
And I’m thinkin’, if I do that, it’s gonna, you know, it’s gonna be the first call that goes straight on the speaker phone,
Yeah.
For like the entire, fire brigade service everywhere,
With a butch hero, carrying you down over his shoulders with your trousers down ‘round your ankles.
Exactly!
Can I not just pull ‘em up?  No – you’ve got to be learned – taught a lesson.
Yeah.  Well I imagine the idea of a, phoning up and going, Hello there, I’m uh, I’m trapped in a room in my house.  Oh yeah?  Which one is it?  Aw, you don’t need to know ..
It’s quite small.  It’s quite small.
Steve laughs
Is it?  Yeah.
It’s not the toilet, is it?  ‘Cause we don’t wanna come and rescue someone who’s trapped in the toilet.  No ..
Which service do you require?  Paper?
Steve laughs

So um, I think I can’t find the fire brigade, the clock’s ticking, so then I think, I think one of my housemates is still in the house but still asleep.  So I phone the house number, right, phone rings and rings and rings for ages, and eventually, he answers the phone, right, he gets out of bed, answers the phone, Yeah.  Hi, it’s Steve, All right, what’s wrong.  I’m downstairs,
What are you doing?  What are you doing?  All right?  Yeah, I didn’t wake you? Oh no.  What are you doing?  Ah, just, in the toilet ..
I’m just downstairs in the toilet,
Oh yeah?  What’ you doin’?  Ah, finish what I’m .. have you got any … toilet paper.
Any bog roll.
Yeah.
So, he had to um, kinda scrape together a few bits of paper, you know, and sort of tin foil, or whatever he could find,
Yeah.
In the house, right.
A cactus.  Oh no!
Pass it underneath the door, right, and I had to, then he, I said, Can you move away from the door, while I, ‘cause I don’t want him to hear me, as I’m, you know, wiping,
You didn’t say that.
Yeah!  Well I didn’t want him to, that’s, that’s embarrassing!
Sorry – what were you – what were you wiping with?  Tumbleweed?  What do you mean?  What noise?
I know what he means.
Yeah.  No, exactly.
Ricky sighs
So um, so then I say, Right, can you
Why was he hovering?
Steve laughs
Why didn’t he want to walk away?  What was he, outside with a glass to his ear?

Yeah.  Yeah.  But thankfully there was a window, in the door, but it was frosted glass.  You could just see my semi-naked body, movin’ around.  And um, so eventually I said to him, Look, listen, I’m gonna need you to sort of kick the door in.  He said, Well, I don’t wanna kick the door in ‘cause we’re gonna have to pay for it, aren’t we, I go Yeah, but I’ve got to go to the World Service, I’ve got – and he was, a lovely man, he’s the weakest man, you’ve ever, you’ve ever come across.  It’s like, if there’s one person you don’t want, to have to throw their bodyweight against a door, it’s him.  It’s like he’ll snap before the door will.  So he’s smashing against the door,
This sounds like a fetish, to me, though.  He went in there, there you were naked, with lots of toilet paper.  And you go, Oh, you’ve broken the door down, and here I am, naked.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Again.
Oh, you’ve rumbled me, Rick!
Ricky laughs
I wish I’d not told that embarrassing story on the radio!  Like it wasn’t embarrassing enough, you’ve just got to make it slightly more seedy.
Oh, so, did he, did he get it down.
He did, yeah, and I got to the World Service with like, minutes to spare.
Ohhh.
And, interestingly, I told that story, to 50 million people around the world.
Did they understand?
I think so.
Well, what, I mean, is that a bit of a problem, when you’re on the World Service, like thinking of things that everyone, can understand.
Yes.
‘Cause you can’t talk about,
It’s a bit like when talking to you, Karl.
Yeah.  Yeah, exactly, Karl.  I think you’re on thin ice there.  Worryin’ about people understanding what you’re saying.
No, but you can’t talk about stuff that’s on the telly and that, ‘cause some people will say, Well, we haven’t even got a telly here.
Ricky laughs
Aw … you’re listening to Xfm 104.9.  Play a record.
Nirvana, All Apologies, on Xfm 104.9.  I’m Ricky Gervais, obviously.  With me Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington, well.  Steve.  I met up with, I know it’s forbidden, usually,
I don’t know why you keep doin’ it!

Let me just explain to the listener, um, me and Steve have got a little bit of a pact.  We’re not allowed to talk to Karl, during the week, because he comes out with too much dynamite, and we want it to be fresh.  And it’s, it’s just unfair.  And if he sees us laughin’, he, he clams up a little bit, ‘cause he, he knows something’s wrong.  With his head.  So, um, I was in a pub, and, Karl called.  Returned call – I called you earlier, didn’t I.  And I said, Oh, I’m just ‘cross, the road – come over.  And uh, he came over, and, we had a conversation, and uh, I kept sayin’, No – save it.  And I can’t remember half the things he was sayin’, but I do remember one thing he said.  He said, that the human eye never grows.  He said, he said, unlike your ears and nose that keeps growing all your life, he says the human eye never grows.  Now there’s a little bit of – he said, Now you look at a baby that’s got big eyes, it’s got the same size eyes as it wil have, when it’s an adult.
When a – when a baby’s born, everyone always goes, Aw, look at it’s eyes.  Don’t they.  ‘Cause that’s like the main feature.
Yes.
Quite big.  They don’t grow, they don’t get any smaller.  They stay the same size.
What, you mean once you become an adult, the same sized eyes,
No.  Soon as you come out the womb, you’re eyes, the size they are, as a little baby, they stay the same size,
Until you die.
And I’m, I said, I pointed out to him, Right, I said, If that was true, Steve Merchant, when he was a baby, with these eyes he’s got now, woulda looked like a hammerhead shark.
All right, calm down.  You don’t wanna go lay into the eyes.
Do you know what I mean?  Just to prove m’point.
I didn’t laugh,
Good.
When he said that.
Respect.
Ricky laughs
D’y’know’t I mean, though?  Imagine –
Well.  I’ve got – the eyes are the windows of the soul!  And mine are, happen to be, enormous,
French windows.
Plate glass windows.
Ricky laughs
But you know.  But nevertheless, they’re beautiful.  People find them beautiful.
Yeah, they’re good, they’re great, yeah, many people do.  Um, but I –
D’you know they don’t have knee caps, either.
My eyes, or … ?
What?
Bab-babies.  When they’re born, they don’t get knee caps until they’re about 2.
Ricky chuckles
They don’t get knee caps?
Is that true?
Yup.
What’you talkin’ about?  But isn’t it like a  - isn’t it bony, part of,
Well no, all the, you’ve got lots more, lot more bones when you’re born than when the rest of your life,
Yeah, you’ve got 300 when you’re born, then 205 when you’re an adult.
Yeah, they all fuse, don’t they.
Do they.
The head’s got to be all soft to come out,
Right.
As we said earlier, ya know,
I wouldn’t know – I’m a shark.
Ricky laughs
Oh, God!
So what did you say when he said about, my eyes being hugely -
OK, get off it!
I said that isn’t nice, ‘cause he’s not here.
Yeah.  Talk about me,
I wait till he’s here when I slag him off.
No, nice one, Karl!  You’re an honourable man!
Aw, this, I know, see, the thing, the thing is, right, that made me think there might be a little bit of truth in this,
There is, as well, the ear thing.  Have you seen that,
That’s true, yeah.
With old men with really long ears.
Yeah.
And big noses.
Yeah.
Do they -
Do they eat buns?  And walk around in the jungle, these old men?
I don’t understand – you mean that the ears and the nose carry on growing?
Yeah, they do.  That’s true.  That’s true.  It’s cartilage, sort of like,
Yeah, but not like, not sort of like Pinocchio.
No, no.  After you’re dead, you leave your body lyin’ around, it’s got huge elephant-type ears!
Really!  If you left ‘em long enough.
Four foot nose!
Incredible!
That’s what – yeah.  Um,
That’s remarkable.

You know the, but you see that, it’s about the focal, um, uh, length, in your eye, you see, ‘cause it’s like a big lens.  So, it makes sense that they couldn’t change that much.  ‘Cause an owl  - d’ya know why an owl turns its head round, sort of like 180 degrees.
No.
‘Cause it can.
“Cause the eyes take up the whole, it’s the biggest eyes in the animal kingdom, the eyes take up the whole of its skull.
Really!
Yeah.  Yeah.  And it has to move its, yeah.
Has it got a brain in it, as well.
It’s got a brain in there, yeah, above the eye, yeah.  When I say the whole of the skull,
Quite.  Yeah.  There’s some space for the brain.
What I meant is, the, the, the 2 diameters of the eyes, is the, diameter of the, skull.
You’ve lost me there, with diameters.
You didn’t like maths, did you.
Nope.  Don’t like maths.  Never understood it.  Couldn’t get to grips with maths.  I don’t know about you, Karl.
Did you do maths, Karl?
How did you do on your exams, in maths?
Ricky chuckles
Karl sighs
Did you enjoy that?  Was your – I’ll bet yours was rather like my theory, which was, why do you need to figure it all out when you’ve got a calculator.
Exactly.
Yeah.  I knew it.
Yeah.  Yeah.
And I agree.
Well let’s play a record and afterwards, I’m gonna be testing you on your homework this week, Karl.
Could we do uh, White Van Man first?
We could do, oh, just to, no, they’ve got to know, what they’re dealing
No, just to remind people -
With, yeah.  Karl’s homework was to read all about, um, as you know, Che Guevara.
Absolutely.
Uh, uh, last week, he did well on Rasputin, didn’t he.
He did very well on Rasputin.  Passed with flying marks there.
Uh, so let’s have a bit of Wu Tang, shall we.
Then let’s have White – Van – Man.
Karl.
White Van Karl!
Yeah.
Wu-Tang Clan - Uzi (Pinky Ring)

Wu Tang Clan there, Steve.  Xfm, 104.9, Ricky Gervais, with Steve Merchant and Karl Pilkington.  Now I just uh, for a moment, something else Karl said in the week.  I know it’s, forbidden to talk to him, but wh- I’ll you this.  He was talkin’ he was very excited about the Friends Reunited, he was a bit nervous, at first, wasn’t he last week.  But he was really getting into it.  Um, and uh, in the pub we were talking to people and he said, I’d, I’d never, go on a reunion, though.  He said I’d never, never do that.
What, a school reunion.
Yeahhh.  And he said, I wouldn’t want to see anyone.  And I went, well I said, I said, Wouldn’t you want to see those, 2 lads with the big heads, and the webbed hands.
Oh yeah.  These were, people you went to school with, were they?
Yeah.
Well I didn’t knock about with ‘em.  They were in the class.
What were they called?
Uhh—ffreaks.
Right.
Ricky titters
Right.
OK.

And uh, he said, Naw, I wouldn’t want to see them, ‘cause what could you say?  Ooh, you haven’t changed much.  Right?  And he went, he said, And they wouldn’t go anyway, would they?  I said Why?  Well they, didn’t have any friends.  And I said, Well, weren’t they friends with each other?  And he went, No, that would have been too obvious.   Like they (? can’t understand ? ) and went, No.  I know it’s tempting, but let’s not.
Everyone would think that’s just what we were gonna do,
Ricky laughs
Yeah.  Yeah.  Yeah.
Let’s not do it.
So they didn’t even – hang around with each other?
No.

(Mumbles) In my – in my head I’ve got summat like, it’s like a, some sort of extra thing from Blake 7, that they’re like some sort of, you know, lagoon monster.  But they just had slightly oversized heads, did they?
See, does your head grow?  Your eyes don’t, does your head, ‘cause maybe they got to a point now that it’s all sort of caught up with each other.
Ricky laughs
Go on!
So at the time the eyes were very small and the head was huge.
Just a very big head.  I mean the fingers aren’t gonna change, you know, that’s not,
They had webbed fingers!
It was like the Penguin, in Batman.
Really!  Are you sure?
No, honestly.
Are you sure they weren’t wearing mittens?
No.  Seriously.
Yeah.  They weren’t – it wasn’t Home Economics.  They weren’t getting summat out of the over, a very hot dish, were they.  Every time you saw them.
But why were they 2, but they weren’t related and they weren’t friends?
Dunno!  I suppose it’s like asthma and that, innit.  It’s like some kids have it, and it’s just a coincidence –
Yeah, but asthma’s quite a common, thing!  Webbed hands, Karl!
Yeah.  I dunno.  You don’t think of it, do ya, really, when you’re a kid.  You just sort of – when ya, when ya first see ‘em,
There goes the Frog Men.
Ricky laughs
Anyway, Karl, let’s have a, let’s have a little quick session of White Van Man.  For those that don’t listen to the show regularly,
Ricky continues to laugh

The Sun has a section called White Van Man where a member of the public is asked their opinions on the week’s big political and social hot potatoes.  Karl, we just thought, uh, it would be fun if you just had some of the questions.  It’s not so much questions, really, it’s just your views on these big, these big news stories.  Uh, what do you make of Olympic ski hero Alain Baxter testing positive for drugs.
What did he do.
Well, he won a gold medal, in the Olympics, and he
For what?
He was a skiier.
Right.
And, he won a gold medal, and they tested him positive for uh, some kind of illegal drug.
But, what, I mean if he did, why take drugs to ski?
Steve laughs
Why take drugs -
‘Cause all you have to do is balance.
But imagine it would be amazin’ if you were stoned, like goin’ down a hill!
Yeah, it’s not like you’re, you’re,
But, it’s, it’s not gonna help you, it’s not like,
No!  It’s just gravity that’s doin’ all the work, innit, with skiing.
Yeah, but it’s often to do with your athleticism, isn’t it.  It’s not,
No, but it would be like sayin’, We’ve just found out the people on the toboggan were on crack.  It’s not – it’s not gonna help ‘em.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, but you –
You sit there, and you go with the flow!  And you try, and you hold on -
Yeah.  Could I just, could I say,
Apparently that’s his defense!
The drugs he was taking, prob’ly, he wasn’t, he prob’ly wasn’t jackin’ up, H, or, y’know, dropping a few Es, or getting stoned.  He was probably taking more sort of, uh,
Steroids.
Performance enhancing drugs.  As opposed to him just like scoring some shit around the corner from someone.
But, but that’s -
Getting off his tits and jumping in a tobbogan!  Doesn’t mean that, does it!
He wasn’t – yeah.  He wasn’t off his nut.
Yeahyeah.  Are you – you – we’ve tested you, you’re pissed out your head!
Why’d’t he just say, Don’t be stupid.  Why would I do that.  It’s not gonna help me out.
But it is, isn’t it!  Because uh, performance enhancing drugs do!
Wait a minute, Steve – wait a minute.  Karl,
Ricky snaps his fingers and claps
Look at this way – look at me – OK, yeah.  Have I got his attention?
Yeah.  The the the – the light’s glinting off your ring there,
Yeahyeah.  Yeah.  OK, right.  Now keep concentrating.  Some athletes, you’re aware they take drugs,  that’s to build up muscle -
Swimmers and stuff.

Yeah.  Swimmers, runners, yeah.  Not only do they help build muscle, but they can actually, y’know, give ‘em a boost, peformance-wise, like steroids, and all, all this sort of stuff, right.  So that’s the sort of thing we’re talkin’ about.  OK.
Right.  So again,
He was- he wasn’t on a bong, before,
Why would that help him?
What!
Why would that help you, when, you’re, all you’ve got to do is balance on skiis!
Not when you’re at the Olympic level!
Yeah.  Yeah.
There’s a lot to do with, y’know, your body, and your legs,
No, it’s practice, innit!  It’s like, if, if you’ve skiied for years, then you’ve got good balance after a bit.
Hold on, Karl.  D’you know what?  You’ve made a mockery of drug taking!  Well done!  All right, next one, Steve.
I hate this bit.  I hate this.
Um, I don’t know if you saw it, what do you make of Posh Spice’s “warts and all” documentary?
Yeah, I saw a bit of it.
What do you make of it?
Uuuuu…I mean, people are slaggin’ ‘em off, aren’t they, saying, y’know, she’s daft and that, but,
They haven’t met you!
Karl laughs
She’s – I, I think they’re all right, honestly.
Yeah.
She’s all right, I mean, I think David’s really, a decent bloke.
Sure.
Um,
Would you agree that he’s quite a simple man?
Yeah, but he’s a footballer, he doesn’t need to be – d’y’know what I mean, it’s like me.
Yeah.
Like, y’know, all right, I only get an E in history.
Sure.
Ricky chuckles
But, knowin’ about the Tudors doesn’t help me press these buttons to put the next CD on.
No.  Sure.
D’y’know’t I mean?
Yeahyeahyeah.  Yup.
So, good luck to him, and he’s done well out of it.  It’s just jealousy.
Yeah?
I remember, though, when I was back in Manchester, I was in Piccadilly Train Station, and he was there, right.  Not as big a star as he is now,
Yeah.
Back then.  But he was stood there, and I was so close to goin’ over to him and saying, Did you go to my school.  Because, I recognised his face, didn’t know who he was.
Oh no!

D’you know when you sort of go, I’m sure I went to school, and it’s not the one with the big head, but I do recognise him.  And me girlfriend got off the train and I said, I’m sure I know him and she said, Yeah, it’s David Beckham.
Oh, thank God for your girlfriend, she get you out of an awful lot of scrapes, does she?
She does, yeah.
OK, um, what about the fact that, the pension crisis,
Sure.
Is gonna force Britons to work into their 70s, Karl.  You might have to carry on working in to your 70s, to claim a pension.
I think it’s a good thing.  Uh, ‘cause you see a lot of old people who look bored.
OK.
Ricky laughs
And I honestly think, if you keep, if you keep your brain busy,
Yeah,
You’ll live longer.
Yeah.

It’s only when you actually shut down, right, that, that’s when your body sort of dies, ‘cause it doesn’t feel it has a purpose.  It’s like if, you’ve got the flu, keep going to work.  If you have a day off you’ll just feel worse.  You’ll mope about at home, doesn’t do you any good,
What about, where do you draw the line there, though.  What if you, say, lose a finger.  Pop in to work?
Um, depends.  If, if you can’t concentrate ‘cause it’s painful,
But what if you’re a typist.
Or a pianist.
You’re not gonna type as many words, but you’ll do more, at work, than you would havin’ a day off at home.
Sure.  OK.  Um, Tony Blair, turning trendy, with his uh, Paul Smith designed naked lady shirt, I don’t know if you’ve seen this, this is the one with pictures of naked ladies on the cuffs.
And – you know, I mean,
OK.  Um, and finally um,
How is that – you see, this is what annoys me about this feature.  It’s just, what’s that – so what?
Yeah, but it’s the pres- it’s the Prime Minister of this country, wearing a trendy shirt, with naked ladies on the cuffs!
All right.

OK!  And, finally, what do you make of the fact that Top of the Pops have banned Will Young singing both tracks, uh, on the number 1 slot.  And consequently, he wasn’t on there at all and he should be.  The first time anyone’s ever made this demand.  He wants to sing both the A and, uh, B side.
Well, he can’t –
A.  It’s double A.
Double A side.
That’s what he wanted to do.
That – that isn’t how it works, is it.
Yeah, I agree.  Yeah.
And the thing is, which one – I mean, at the end of the day, loads of people have bought it, haven’t they.  Isn’t it like one of the best -
Yes.  Yes.
So it doesn’t really matter what they do, just people have got it, they can listen to what song they want at home.  It doesn’t matter what Top of the Pops do.
Yes.
And, it’s just annoyed me now.  I don’---it’s,
Who’s annoyed you?

Just what goes on in the world!  I tell you what, you’re better off not knowin’!  I – it’s better bein’ in my little world.  Iff that’s what people are talkin’ about in the streets.  Askin’ the White Van Man.  D’y’know’t I mean?
You’re right, Karl.  I think you’re right.
Jeez.
Shall I – shall I play a lovely song for you, ‘cause you’re gettin’ all stressed now, aren’t ya.
I’ve not had a good day.

No, I know.  I’ll tell you about that later, ‘cause he’s not had a good day.  Well I’m gonna play uh, um, a Neil Young track here, off Harvest.  It’s Alabama. It’s, it’s beautiful, and this is for Karl.
Neil Young - Alabama
Athlete.  West Side.  I still like that one.
It’s a good track.
Yeah, I was worried it was bit – nov – it would go off very quickly.
No, it’s not bad at all.
On Xfm 104.9, I’m Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant, Karl Pilkington.  Steve.

Well, we were talkin’ about the news just now, and um, there was a story I heard in the week, and I think – it was on the radio, and I don’t know all the details, but what I heard was that a number of, I think it was Falkland, uh, maybe Gulf War, war veterans, were I think suing, or complaining to the government, ‘cause they wanted compensation for Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  Now, I don’t know all the ins and outs of it, but it seems to me, that if you’re in the army, and you’re a soldier, a certain degree of trauma, is kind of inevitable.
